channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukrainian President Says Russian Troops Have Crossed the Border
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko canceled a planned visit to Turkey and convened a meeting to focus on the “marked aggravation of the situation” in the southeast part of his country.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Aleksandr Zakharchenko, a rebel commander and the prime minister of the Donetsk People’s Republic, said on Thursday that Russians, including active-duty soldiers on leave, had been fighting against Ukrainian government forces.

item.title: Ebola Could Eventually Afflict Over 20,000, W.H.O. Says
item.description: The World Health Organization reported that the epidemic was still accelerating and could afflict almost seven times the current number of reported cases before it can be brought under control.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Officials handing out food in West Point, Liberia, a region hit hard by Ebola. The death toll from the disease has risen to 1,552 in four countries: Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Nigeria.

item.title: In Israel’s South, Families Worry About the Future of Life Near Gaza
item.description: The latest Gaza conflict, the third in less than six years, has led some parents to question whether they want to continue living near the border.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A girl from Kibbutz Nahal Oz played in a paddle pool in Urim, which is a short drive away but out of mortar range.

item.title: Thai Court Dismisses Ex-Premier’s Murder Case
item.description: Judges from the Criminal Court of Thailand ruled that they lack jurisdiction over former officials who ordered a move against protesters in 2010.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Indian Muslim Said to Have Joined ISIS Is Reported Dead
item.description: Arif Majeed was one of four young Indian men believed to have been recruited online to join the militant group in Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Turkey’s Imperial Fantasy
item.description: The new prime minister's dreams of a Turkish-led Islamic Union are unrealistic.
item.dc:creator: By BEHLUL OZKAN

item.title: Editorial: Political Mischief in the Philippines
item.description: President Aquino threatens to seek a second term and to limit the power of the Supreme Court.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Russia Goes to War With McDonald’s, Soviet Style
item.description: By going after McDonald’s, the Kremlin is once again turning the restaurant chain into a symbol of openness.
item.dc:creator: By MASHA GESSEN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese High Schoolers’ Harsh Military Training Leads to Internet Firestorm
item.description: Incoming high school freshmen in China are required to submit to a week of military drills, but several sessions that have gone awry this year have resulted in a storm of criticism on social media.
item.dc:creator: By BECKY DAVIS

item.title: Officials ‘Cautiously Optimistic’ Missing Malaysian Jet Will Be Found
item.description: As Australia, China and Malaysia reached agreements Thursday on continuing the search for Flight 370, one official said a failed satellite phone call had provided new data.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Media Tycoon Critical of China Is Visited by Hong Kong Antigraft Agency
item.description: Leaked documents suggested that Jimmy Lai had made substantial donations to local pro-democracy parties and politicians.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Stephon Marbury the Musical: A Tale of Making It in Beijing
item.description: The mutual love affair between the former N.B.A. player and his adopted home of Beijing will reach a new milestone this fall when “I Am Stephon Marbury,” a musical about his life in China, opens in the capital.
item.dc:creator: By BECKY DAVIS
item.media:description: The former N.B.A. player Stephon Marbury holding up the trophy in 2012 as his team, the Beijing Ducks, celebrated its first Chinese championship.

item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: Assassin for Escobar Released
item.description: A man who confessed to hundreds of murders as the lead assassin for the drug kingpin Pablo Escobar has been freed from a maximum-security prison under heavy police guard.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: 3 McDonald’s Shut for 90 Days
item.description: Russian courts ordered three McDonald’s restaurants in Moscow shuttered for the maximum period of 90 days over sanitary code violations, Russian news agencies reported.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Helen Bamber, Therapist to Torture Victims, Dies at 89
item.description: Ms. Bamber’s method involved revisiting victims’ worst horrors and letting her clients work them out.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Helen Bamber, before the New York showing in 2009 of the art installation “Journey,” which depicts human trafficking.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Likely Premier Is Party Leader
item.description: Ahmet Davutoglu was elected leader of the governing Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P., on Wednesday, ahead of his expected appointment as prime minister on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: The Netherlands: 173 Victims Identified From DNA Found in Flight Wreckage
item.description: Experts working to identify the victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 say they have positively identified 173 of them from DNA samples.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Israel’s South, Families Worry About the Future of Settlements Near Gaza
item.description: This latest Gaza conflict, the third in less than six years, has led some parents to question whether they want to continue living near the border.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A girl from Kibbutz Nahal Oz played in a paddle pool in Urim, which is a short drive away but out of mortar range.

item.title: Iran Altering Reactor in Bid for Nuclear Deal
item.description: The nation’s top nuclear official said the reactor would be redesigned to limit the amount of plutonium it could produce.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Hamid Foroutan/Iranian Students News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Iran’s nuclear reactor in Arak, about 150 miles southwest of Tehran, is being redesigned.

item.title: Skirmishes Put Feeling of Wartime on India-Pakistan Border
item.description: Nightly artillery firing across the border intensified in mid-August and reportedly has killed two Indian civilians and four Pakistani civilians.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muhammad Shadeen at home in Jora Farm, India, where his son and grandson died when a mortar round shot from Pakistan landed outside the house.

item.title: Military Skill and Terrorist Technique Fuel Success of ISIS
item.description: As fighters continue to seize territory, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria has built an effective management structure of mostly middle-aged Iraqis, including many military officers under Saddam Hussein.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Ukraine Reports Russian Invasion on a New Front
item.description: Tanks, artillery and infantry have crossed from Russia into an unbreached part of eastern Ukraine in recent days, in what Ukrainian and Western military officials are calling a stealth invasion.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers regrouped in a defensive position after coming under heavy shelling in Novoazovsk, a border town near Russia in southeastern Ukraine.

item.title: Rio De Janeiro Journal: From a Compound in the Brazilian Hills, Excellence in Math Emerges
item.description: The National Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics in Rio is gaining attention as a hidden gem in a country with few world-renowned educational institutions.
item.category: Embraer - Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA|ERJ|NYSE
National Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Ana Carolina Fernandes for The New York Times
item.media:description: The leafy campus of the National Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: As Truce Holds, Dazed Gazans Get to Work
item.description: Palestinian workers began clearing rubble and repairing damage from Israeli attacks as residents returned home, but some residents of southern Israel remained wary of the cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: Palestinian men on Wednesday in the ruins of Shejaiya, an eastern neighborhood of Gaza City and the scene of the heaviest fighting during the seven-week conflict with Israel.

item.title: Proposing New Capital Is Old Idea in Argentina
item.description: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner’s suggestion to consider making Santiago del Estero the nation’s capital reflects longstanding tension between Buenos Aires and Argentina’s provinces.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
